Maintaining your emotional fitness is a legal requirement

Under the Emotional Accountability Act of 2019, all U.S. residents age 18 and older must maintain a valid emotional fitness license. Failure to comply may result in a written warning, mandatory counseling, or a $340 fine that we will feel bad about issuing.

The Bureau of Emotional Fitness (BEF) was established by Executive Order 14027 to ensure that all Americans maintain a minimum standard of emotional health. We operate 1,200 field offices across the country. Average wait time is 2 hours and 14 minutes. We know. We are working on it. We have been working on it since 2019.

Our mission: "To ensure that every American is emotionally fit, or at minimum, aware that they are not."

The Assessment Process

1

Arrive at Your Local BEF Office

Bring two forms of ID, your current emotional fitness license (if renewing), and Form EF-47 (completed in black ink — blue ink will be accepted but Diane will sigh). Take a number. The number will be high. Sit down.

2

Complete the Emotional Intake Questionnaire

The questionnaire is 14 pages. Page 6 asks you to "describe your relationship with impermanence in three sentences or fewer." Page 11 asks if you have cried in the last 30 days and, if so, to rate the cry on a scale from "light mist" to "full collapse." There is no page 13. This is not an error. We removed it. It was too sad.

3

In-Person Assessment with a Certified Evaluator

A BEF evaluator will sit across from you at a small desk and ask you how you're doing. You must answer honestly. "Fine" is not accepted. "Fine" has not been accepted since 2021, when the Bureau determined that 98% of people who said "fine" were not, in fact, fine. Your evaluator may or may not make eye contact. This depends on Diane's mood. You do not get to choose your evaluator. It is usually Diane.

4

Receive Your Score

Scores range from 0 (emotionally inert) to 100 (suspiciously well-adjusted). A score of 55 or above is passing. The national average is 61. Diane's personal average score, if she were to take her own assessment, would be — and this is her estimate — "maybe a 40 on a good day." She has not been formally assessed. Evaluators are exempt. This is a policy she advocated for.

EF-90 Request for Emotional Hardship Extension 4 For residents experiencing "a time." Documentation of the time is required.
EF-6B Mandatory Remedial Course Enrollment 6 Required if score is below 55. Course is 6 weeks. Homework is "journaling." Diane checks.
EF-W Workplace Emotional Compliance Certificate 2 Employers with 50+ staff must file annually. Most forget. We send reminders. They ignore them.

All forms available at your local BEF office. They are not available online. We had a PDF once. The link broke. Gerald in IT said he would fix it. Gerald left in 2023.

Meet Our Staff

Diane Kowalczyk

SENIOR EMOTIONAL EVALUATOR · 27 YEARS

Diane has worked at the Bureau since its inception. Before that, she worked at the DMV for 22 years. She describes the transition as "lateral." Diane has assessed over 14,000 residents. She does not smile during assessments. She says smiling "introduces bias." Her colleagues say Diane does not smile during non-assessments either. Diane is aware of this feedback. She has filed it.

Marcus Webb

EMOTIONAL EVALUATOR II · 4 YEARS

Marcus joined the Bureau after a career in social work. He is the only evaluator who asks follow-up questions. Residents describe him as "surprisingly warm for a government employee." Diane considers Marcus "enthusiastic," which in Diane's vocabulary is neither a compliment nor an insult. Marcus scored a 78 on his own assessment. He told Diane. She said "okay."

Priya Nair

REMEDIAL COURSE INSTRUCTOR · 3 YEARS

Priya teaches the 6-week mandatory emotional fitness course for residents who score below 55. The course includes journaling, breathing exercises, and a group discussion that Priya describes as "challenging" and the participants describe as "like jury duty but for your feelings." Priya's course has a 72% pass rate. The 28% who fail are required to take it again. One man has taken it four times. Priya knows him by name. She worries about him.

Director Patricia Hollowell

BUREAU DIRECTOR · APPOINTED 2019

Director Hollowell was appointed by the President to lead the Bureau. She has a Master's in Public Administration and a "complicated relationship with optimism." She visits field offices quarterly and asks staff how they're doing. Diane once answered "present." Director Hollowell wrote this down. She has not asked Diane again.

Frequently Asked Questions

Why is emotional fitness a legal requirement?

The Emotional Accountability Act of 2019 was passed after a congressional study found that 74% of Americans described their emotional state as "I don't know, fine I guess." Congress determined this was insufficient. The Act requires all adults to demonstrate a baseline level of emotional awareness. The vote was 51-49. The dissenting senators described themselves as "fine."

Can I take the assessment online?

No. The Bureau briefly offered online assessments in 2022. Within three weeks, 40,000 residents submitted questionnaires that were, in Diane's words, "clearly not honest." One resident described their relationship with impermanence as "lol." The online portal was shut down. Gerald in IT was supposed to archive the data. Gerald left. The data is on Gerald's laptop. We do not know where Gerald is.

What happens if I fail?

Residents who score below 55 are enrolled in a mandatory 6-week remedial course taught by Priya Nair. The course meets Tuesday evenings from 6:30 to 8:00 PM in Room 4B of your local BEF office. There is homework. The homework is journaling. Priya reads every journal entry. She says this is "the hardest part of her job, but also the most important." Dennis from Cleveland has submitted 412 journal entries across four course cycles. Priya has read all of them. She says Dennis is "making progress." Dennis disagrees.

Can I appeal my score?

Yes. File Form EF-12 within 30 days of your assessment. Appeals are reviewed by a senior evaluator, which at every field office in the country is Diane. Diane has received 847 appeals in five years. She has approved three. The three successful appeals were all cases where, in Diane's assessment, "the resident was having a genuinely bad day and the score did not reflect their typical emotional state." When asked how she determines this, Diane said: "I know." She did not elaborate.

Is the staff emotionally fit?

Bureau evaluators are exempt from assessment under Section 4(c) of the Emotional Accountability Act. This exemption was proposed by Diane in 2020 and approved unanimously. Director Hollowell has suggested "voluntary staff assessments" twice. Both times, Diane looked at her. Both times, the suggestion was withdrawn. Marcus once voluntarily shared his score of 78 during a staff meeting. The room was silent. Diane said "okay." The topic has not been raised since.

Visit Your Local BEF Office

Hours: Monday–Friday, 8:00 AM – 4:30 PM. Closed federal holidays and the third Wednesday of each month, which Diane has designated as "administrative recovery." Nobody has asked what she is recovering from.

What to bring: Two forms of ID, completed Form EF-47 (black ink), your current license (if renewing), and "an openness to being honest with yourself for possibly the first time" (Priya's suggestion — now printed on the door).

Average wait time: 2 hours 14 minutes. This is an improvement from 2021 (3 hours 40 minutes). Diane has said "you're welcome" about this once, to no one in particular.
